title: Michelle Obama is the president's middle-class messenger
content:
Middle-class dreams are 'what ’ s at stake ' in this election , Michelle Obama said Tuesday . Obama 's middle-class messenger
President Barack Obama ’ s pitch to voters this year centers on his fight for the middle class at what he calls a make-or-break moment .
The problem : His exotic life story and rise to the presidency don ’ t help him connect with struggling swing voters — people who are still feeling the effects of the economic downturn and leaning toward Mitt Romney .
Honolulu and Harvard have been replaced by his grandparents ’ financial struggles , his single mother and his wife ’ s story . All their struggles have been conflated into “ our family ’ s story , ” as the president described it while touring the Rust Belt last week .
“ When I think about both Michelle ’ s family and my family , what I am reminded of is what made America great was this basic idea , this basic bargain , that all of you experienced in your own families … [ that ] here in America , you could make it if you try , ” he said last week in Poland , Ohio .
And the first lady is making the case herself . As she speaks at fundraisers and grassroots rallies — including the two she did Tuesday in Florida — Michelle Obama turns back to her roots to contrast herself with the always-comfortable Romneys : She grew up in a “ little-bitty apartment ” on Chicago ’ s South Side that her mother still lives in ( when not at the White House ) , her father working long days at a city water plant while fighting multiple sclerosis , and both parents pushing their children to work hard and achieve more in their lives .
Those stories aren ’ t new — she talked about her upbringing during the last campaign as well — but they ’ ve taken on a central role in nearly every public event she does . And in the context of a continued downturn where Americans continue to struggle , they ’ ve taken on increased importance .
Connecting to the middle class story is “ even more important in this election than in the last election , ” said Democratic pollster Celinda Lake . “ The last was about inspiration . This one is about who ’ s more in touch with my life , who ’ s able to understand my problems and make them better . ”
The Obama campaign is well aware of how powerful the first lady is in making this case .
“ There ’ s no doubt that she [ has ] a story that many Americans share , and values that many Americans share , ” senior adviser David Axelrod said from Chicago .
The first lady ’ s story reflects “ the America she believes in — a country where if you work hard you can get ahead and your kids can get even farther , ” Axelrod said . “ And that ’ s really at the essence of what the president is fighting for . ”
Speaking Tuesday at a rally in Miami , the first lady “ Growing up , I saw how my parents saved and sacrificed , and poured everything they had into me and my brother . They held us to the same high standard of excellence because they wanted us both to have the kind of education they could only dream of , ” the first lady said Tuesday in Miami . “ How many people can relate to that ? ”
Middle class dreams are “ what ’ s at stake ” in this election , she continued , repeating lines from her standard stump speech . “ That ’ s what we ’ re fighting for — that fundamental promise that no matter who you are or how you started out , if you work hard , you can build a decent life for yourself and an even better life for your kids . That is the American Dream . That is it . ”
